Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterizing the Roles of Atmospheric Structure and Clouds on the Radiation and Precipitation Budgets at Summit, Greenland
Award.AbstractNarration:
Funds are provided to characterize the interactions among the atmospheric state, cloud properties, radiation, and precipitation at Summit, Greenland. The objective is to investigate a number of important cloud-related processes, how these interact with the Arctic climate system, and their impact on the surface energy and mass budgets. Specific foci will include:
1) Low-cloud persistence mechanisms that lead to long-lived Arctic stratiform clouds, which interact strongly with the atmospheric structure and surface energy budget;
2) Cloud-phase partitioning, which determines the cloud microphysical composition and, ultimately, the effects that clouds have on atmospheric radiation and the hydrologic cycle; and
3) Precipitation partitioning, in order to understand the different modes of precipitation at Summit and how these impact the total surface accumulation.
To address these topics, this project will utilize detailed observations from a suite of ground-based remote sensors deployed at Summit as part of the NSF/AON-funded ICECAPS project in combination with data from satellite-borne active remote sensors. High-resolution numerical modeling will also be used to investigate many of the fine-scale cloud processes and their mesoscale influences. These studies over the Greenland Ice Sheet will also be considered within the context of similar measurements and model studies made at other Arctic locations in order to understand these important processes over Summit and, in a more general sense, across the Arctic.

Atmospheric water vapor, clouds, and precipitation greatly affect the surface energy and cryospheric mass balances in the Arctic, and are responsible for much of the variability in these balances. It is thought that recent rapid melting of Arctic sea ice may be driven, in part, by changes in cloud cover and radiation. Cloud-related processes and feedbacks are known to be one of the greatest sources of uncertainty in global climate models, and these shortcomings have been clearly identified in model simulations over the Arctic. Thus, the results of this project should improve our understanding of Arctic cloud processes and their inclusion in climate models, which, in turn, will improve predictability.

As broader impacts of this research, the project will provide important data analysis and integration experience for four new graduate students at the participating universities. In addition, data and results from this study will be integrated into undergraduate coursework and summer workshops for high school students and teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has aimed to better understand the local and large-scale processes that impact the surface radiation, energy and mass budgets of the Greenland ice sheet. These processes are very important for understanding the long-term trajectory of the ice sheet, including melt processes and their ultimate impact on sea-level rise. The University of Colorado’s contribution to this multi-institution collaborative project has focused on the drivers of surface energy budget variability using a combination of observations, models, and reanalyses.

Observationally, we have used measurements from Summit Station, Greenland to derive all terms of the surface energy budget including radiation, turbulence, and sub-surface heat fluxes. We have also derived key properties related to atmospheric structure, precipitation, cloud properties, and cloud radiative forcing. Using this set of parameters, we derived seasonally-dependent relationships between different terms that represent how energy is partitioned at the surface throughout the full annual cycle. These observationally-derived relationships were then used to assess how large-scale models represent these same processes, revealing important model deficiencies in representing surface albedo, low-atmosphere structure, sub-surface processes, and cloud composition.

A regional mesoscale model was then used to examine similar processes over the whole Greenland sub-continent. First, the model was assessed using our sophisticated observations, demonstrating skill at representing the different surface energy terms, the evolution of surface albedo, and the spatial distribution of surface melt during a key event. With confidence in the model’s ability to represent important processes, we then conducted sensitivity studies by varying the impact of the clouds within the model to quantify the full role of clouds in causing ice melt at the Greenland surface. This same model was also used as a framework for understanding how large-scale transport of moisture and local vertical interactions in the atmosphere work together to ultimately determine the properties and impacts of the clouds on the surface.

Interactions between large-scales and local scales were further examined using a technique called Self Organizing Maps (SOM). This technique uses output from the National Centers for Environmental Prediction (NCEP) reanalysis product to classify large-scale meteorological states into a limited number of categories. The large-scale meteorological states associated with these categories control the winds and advection over Greenland. We then mapped observational data from Summit, Greenland onto the SOM nodes to examine the relationships between the large-scale state and variability of local temperature, clouds, radiation, and moisture. This analysis revealed the large-scale weather patterns that most often lead to extreme warming events over Greenland in both summer and winter.

Overall, the project has developed numerous data products that are now publicly available for use by others in their studies of the Greenland ice sheet. It has also contributed to the assessment and advancement of modeling tools at multiple institutions including the University of Colorado and the National Center for Atmospheric Research. Lastly, the project has contributed to graduate level education for three students, including two that have now successfully completed a Master’s degree and a PhD degree.
